fields.display_name: Research Computing and Data Outreach (Initial Contact)
Research Computing and Data Advanced Support
Research Computing Management of the Research Lifecycle
Research Data Curation, Storage, Backup, and Transfer
Software Portability, Containers and Cloud Computing
Change Mngmnt, version control, administration, and ticketing
Best security practices for open environments
Partnerships and Engagement with External Communities
Professional Development of Research Computing and Data Staff

fields.description: Note: This does not impact the overall computed coverage for the Researcher-Facing.
Note: This does not impact the overall computed coverage for the Data-Facing.
Note: This does not impact the overall computed coverage for the Software-Facing.
Note: This does not impact the overall computed coverage for the Systems-Facing.
Note: This does not impact the overall computed coverage for the Strategy and Policy-Facing.

question: researcher
staffing
training
fields.text: Do researchers have access to introductory user support and training related to the use of research computing and data resources available at local, regional, and national level?
fields.help_text: That is, are there researcher-facing engagement and support staff who provide this? This often includes staff (and, at some institutions, students) who have the role of training and consulting on basic use of resources. This may include a combination of Research Computing and Data staff, Data Librarians, and staff in partner organizations. It will generally include training and support materials (documentation, recorded webinars and/or presentations, etc.).

question: researcher
staffing
professional-development
fields.text: Are researcher-facing staff provided with professional development and networking opportunities?

question: researcher
staffing
broad-support
fields.text: Do researcher-facing staff have the skills and capacity to broadly support researchers across levels (graduate students to PIs) and across domains with information about the use and effectiveness of new technologies?

question: researcher
staffing
advocacy
fields.text: Can researcher-facing staff effectively serve as advocates for the research community to leadership and IT governance?

question: researcher
staffing
vision
fields.text: To what extent is there a clear vision, effective guidance, and strategy for the allocation and prioritization of support resources/personnel?

question: researcher
outreach
proactive-outreach
fields.text: Is there an institutional practice to proactively reach out to researchers, new faculty, or prospective faculty to explain research support services and help with computing beyond the desktop?
fields.help_text: For example, this could happen during discussions with prospective faculty or graduate students, or as part of the onboarding or orientation for new researchers.

question: researcher
outreach
community-engagement
fields.text: Do researcher-facing staff have the skills and capacity to effectively engage in community outreach and broader impacts?

question: researcher
outreach
awareness
fields.text: Are researchers made aware of research computing and data related resources?
fields.help_text:
i.   intra-campus resources (e.g., support, training, engineering, central IT services, library services, related centers or institutes)
  ii.  cross-institution, regional, national, and/or international entities that comprise the larger ecosystem of Research Computing and Data (e.g., ACI-REF, Campus Champions, Research Software Engineers, CASC, CaRCC, CI Engineers, PEARC)?

question: researcher
outreach
assessment
fields.text: Does your institution have a process to assess researcher awareness, satisfaction, and engagement related to Research Computing and Data services and support?
fields.help_text: This might include periodic satisfaction surveys, or another assessment mechanism.

question: researcher
outreach
impact
fields.text: Does your institution have a process to assess the impact of research computing and data support?
fields.help_text: This often includes things like publications, grants, etc. for active users, as well as faculty and graduate student recruitment and retention cases supported. It may include profiles of and quotes from active research users.

question: researcher
outreach
marketing
fields.text: Does your institution have marketing/communication resources (staff) with the skills and capacity to help publicize and explain research support services?

question: researcher
consulting
training
fields.text: Do researchers have access to application support (training, help) for standard software packages, middleware, libraries, and modules?

question: researcher
consulting
efficiency
fields.text: Do researcher-facing staff have the skills and capacity to diagnose inefficiencies, monitor usage, and advise on policies and optimizations to make for more efficient utilization of research computing and data resources?

question: researcher
consulting
emerging-technologies
fields.text: Are researcher-facing staff engaged with exploring, testing, and deploying emerging or advanced technologies to help research?

question: researcher
consulting
documentation
fields.text: Do researcher-facing staff regularly and effectively document processes, policies, and resources both internally and for the user community?

question: researcher
lifecycle
proposal-development
fields.text: Are researchers supported across the full research lifecycle?
fields.help_text: I.e., are researchers supported during proposal development, during the active award, and post funding? This may include support for project planning and proposal development, as well as providing research computing and data services.

question: researcher
lifecycle
compliance
fields.text: Do researchers have access to advice on research compute and data compliance, security, management, and governance?

question: data
creation
lifecycle
fields.text: Do researchers have access to consulting or other resources on data lifecycle requirements during data creation?
fields.help_text: For example, consulting, websites, hand-outs, or other resources providing support to anticipate requirements for metadata, storage, and reuse; publisher requirements; and/or funder requirements.

question: data
creation
discovery
fields.text: Do researchers have access to consulting or other resources supporting data discovery?
fields.help_text: I.e., consulting, websites, hand-outs, or other resources to help identify appropriate data repositories (on campus, in domains, and more generally). Note: this may come from Research Computing and Data staff, library staff, or other partners.

question: data
discovery
terms-of-service
fields.text: Do researchers have access to expertise about common Terms of Service for frequently crawled websites/data repositories and best practices guidance?
fields.help_text:
Examples of this can include:
  • Are there library or other staff with knowledge about common Terms of Service for frequently crawled websites/data repositories and best practices guidance?
  • Are there library or other staff with skills and capacity to inform policies and educate researchers on data use agreements (DUAs)?

question: data
discovery
collection
fields.text: Do researchers have access to software supporting data collection?
fields.help_text: For example, do they have access to software for data crawling, for web-scraping, for data-gathering, and similar activities to collect data?

question: data
discovery
software-development
fields.text: Do researchers have access to resources (e.g., staff) to develop software supporting data discovery and collection?
fields.help_text:
For example, do they have access to software developers to develop software for:
  • data collection (including web crawling/scraping/etc.).
  • user interfaces or web applications to collect and interact with data with appropriate security protocols and policies.

question: data
analysis
wrangling-support
fields.text: Do researchers have access to consulting, expertise, or other resources on data wrangling/manipulation and data analysis?

question: data
analysis
wrangling-software
fields.text: Do researchers have access to software that supports data wrangling/manipulation and data analysis?

question: data
analysis
wrangling-resources
fields.text: Do researchers have access to dedicated resources (e.g., staff) who can perform data wrangling/manipulation and data analysis?

question: data
analysis
software-development
fields.text: Do researchers have access to resources (e.g., staff) for software development of tools that support data wrangling/manipulation and data analysis?

question: data
visualization
consulting
fields.text: Do researchers have access to consulting, expertise, or other resources on data visualization?

question: data
visualization
software
fields.text: Do researchers have access to software that supports data visualization?

question: data
visualization
resources
fields.text: Do researchers have access to dedicated resources (e.g., staff) who can perform data wrangling/manipulation and data analysis?

question: data
visualization
software-development
fields.text: Do researchers have access to resources (e.g., staff) for software development of tools that support data visualization?

question: data
curation
consulting
fields.text: Do researchers have access to consulting, expertise, or other resources to help them identify appropriate data repositories (on campus, in domains, and more generally) to place their data?

question: data
curation
resources
fields.text: Do researchers have access to resources (e.g., staff) who can advise and assist with database creation and data organization?

question: data
curation
software
fields.text: Do researchers have access to tools/software that supports data backup, storage, and integrity checking?

question: data
curation
software-development
fields.text: Do researchers have access to resources (e.g., staff) who will develop tools/software that supports data backup, storage, and integrity checking?

question: data
curation
big-data
fields.text: Do researchers have access to software and/or environments to deal with datasets that exceed what is generally available to individuals on a workstation or personal storage subscription?

question: data
curation
metadata
fields.text: Do researchers have access to consulting, expertise, or other resources on metadata design and use?
fields.help_text:
Example areas of available consulting, expertise, websites, hand-outs, or other resources could include:
  • Establishing controlled vocabularies for metadata and metadata fields for repository systems.
  • Help with designing metadata applicable to their research.
  • Assistance in setting up metadata for reusable data sets, physical samples, research software.

question: data
curation
identifiers
fields.text: Do researchers have access to tools, consulting, expertise, or other resources on good practices for use of identifiers?
fields.help_text:
Examples of good practice include:
  • researchers are encouraged to use researcher identifiers; e.g., ORCiD (https://orcid.org/), ResearcherID (https://www.researcherid.com/), Scopus Author ID, etc.
  • researcher identifiers are supported in the enterprise directory.
  • researchers have access to mechanisms/services to establish unique digital identifiers (DOIs) for data.

question: data
policy
governance
fields.text: Does your institution have research data governance processes in place to establish data policies for research data?

question: data
policy
training
fields.text: Do researchers have access to information and training on research data policy?
fields.help_text:
Example areas of information and training could include:
  • Processes to support and inform users on policy compliance.
  • Training on research data security protocols.
  • Support for Data Management Plan (DMP) development.

question: data
policy
assessment
fields.text: Do researchers have access to support for analysis of research data sensitivity?
fields.help_text:
This may include:
  • Data Use Agreement (DUA) review/analysis and consulting.
  • Institutional Review Board (IRB) templates for datasets (with human or animal subjects), from small datasets that don't need HPC, up to large datasets that need HPC or Cloud services.
  • Support at the nexus of the IRB, legal counsel, and an office of sponsored programs.

question: data
policy
expertise
fields.text: Do researchers have access to expertise and policy infrastructure to manage and use sensitive data?
fields.help_text:
This may include:
  • Data Management Plan (DMP) compliance services (institutional framework, etc.).
  • Consulting, expertise, or other resources on contracts and government mandated data controls (e.g. FISMA, CUI, NIST 800-171, FEDRAMP, HIPAA, NAGPRA/Indigenous data rights).

question: data
policy
preservation
fields.text: Has your institution defined and deployed a process for identifying which research data to archive, preserve, or discard?

question: data
policy
preservation-expertise
fields.text: Do researchers have access to planning expertise for storing, archival and preservation of research data beyond the term of grant funding?
fields.help_text: For example, do researchers' DMPs regularly include planning for the physical and/or cyber resources and facilities (including those supplied by third parties) that will provide data storage, archival, and/or preservation after the grant ends?

question: data
security
moderately-sensitive
fields.text: Do researchers have access to compute and data environments to manage and use moderately sensitive data?
fields.help_text:
For example, NIH dbGaP data controls. Support can include:
  • tools, systems, and environments that can scale from small to large data sets (i.e., from workstations to VMs and up to high performance computing).
  • data security protocols in use, and monitored.

question: data
security
notice-triggering
fields.text: Do researchers have access to compute and data environments to manage and use “notice triggering” data?
fields.help_text:
For example, PHI, HIPAA, Export Control, licensed data. Support can include:
  • tools, systems, and environments that can scale from small to large data sets (i.e., up to high performance computing).
  • data security protocols in use, and monitored.

question: data
security
extremely-sensitive
fields.text: Do researchers have access to compute and data environments to manage and use extremely sensitive data?
fields.help_text: For example, data requiring cold room/air-gapped storage and computing, closely monitored access, dedicated data stewardship etc.

question: software
management
installation
fields.text: Do researchers have access to support for research software package compilation and installation?

question: software
management
installation-training
fields.text: Do researchers have access to support, facilitation or training on how to compile, install, and deploy research software?
fields.help_text: For example, The Carpentries, documentation on how to install and deploy anaconda environment, etc.

question: software
management
assessment
fields.text: Do researchers have access to support for research software package assessment, documentation, and validation?
fields.help_text: That is, support to assess and document security issues, sustainability issues, export control issues, etc. associated with a software package of possible interest to researchers.

question: software
development
resources
fields.text: Do researchers have access to resources (e.g., staff) who can develop research software?
fields.help_text: For example, staff to be written into grants to architect or develop specific research applications or workflow components.

question: software
development
resources-general
fields.text: Do researchers have access to resources (e.g., staff) who can develop software for wide usage?
fields.help_text: This may include software for websites, portals, etc.

question: software
development
security-validation
fields.text: Do researchers have access to security validation for research software?
fields.help_text: For example, analysis for vulnerabilities that can be exploited by hackers, especially for locally developed software.

question: software
development
usability-testing
fields.text: Do researchers have access to usability testing for research software developed on campus?

question: software
development
accessibility
fields.text: Do researchers have access to software or website accessibility consulting, expertise, or other resources (e.g., assessment tools, etc.)?

question: software
optimization
tools
fields.text: Do researchers have access to performance optimizing tools?
fields.help_text: For example, Allinea/ARM Map, Intel VTune, etc.

question: software
optimization
consulting
fields.text: Do researchers have access to support and consulting to optimize software?
fields.help_text: For example, to parallelize code, to port to GPUs or other new architectures, to analyze and improve efficiency, etc.

question: software
optimization
diagnostic-tools
fields.text: Do researchers have access to diagnostic and troubleshooting software?
fields.help_text: For example, Allinea DDT, Intel Inspector, etc.

question: software
optimization
diagnostic-consulting
fields.text: Do researchers have access to support and consulting for diagnosing and troubleshooting software?
fields.help_text: For example, when migrating codes to new cluster environments, new operating systems, etc. This does not include deeper code porting or rewrite for new hardware, GPUs, etc.

question: software
workflow
packages
fields.text: Do researchers have access to support for research workflow packages?
fields.help_text: For example, Toil, Pegasus, NextFlow, etc.

question: software
workflow
consulting
fields.text: Do researchers have access to expertise and basic support to develop or script data workflows?
fields.help_text:
For example:
  • support for initializing a research computing and data workflow?
  • consulting on basic, common workflows, or guidance on good practices in developing custom workflows?

question: software
workflow
support-staff
fields.text: Do researchers have access to dedicated staff resources to develop or script data workflows?
fields.help_text:
For example:
  • authoring of advanced or specific workflows for given research areas (e.g., for genomics, for clinical research, for social sciences, etc.).
  • support for optimizing a research computing and data workflow?

This does not/need not include complete implementation of workflows.

question: software
portability
support
fields.text: Do researchers have access to support for making software portable?
fields.help_text: For example, software repositories, containerization, etc.

question: software
portability
cloud-training
fields.text: Do researchers have access to guidance or training for cloud computing?
fields.help_text:
This can include:
  • Local private campus cloud infrastructure
  • National (e.g., XSEDE-supported) cloud infrastructure
  • Commercial cloud platforms (e.g., AWS, Azure, GCP, etc.)

question: software
portability
cloud-resources
fields.text: Do researchers have access to dedicated resources (e.g., staff) for architecting and deploying cloud solutions?
fields.help_text:
This can be platform independent, and may include:
  • Platform evaluation/comparison, cost estimation
  • Orchestration design and development (Kubernetes, Puppet, Chef, etc.)

question: software
access
authentication
fields.text: Do researchers have access to credential systems as an element of software security?
fields.help_text: For example, access to and support for integration with systems like CAS, Shibboleth, SAML, Single-Sign-on, etc.

question: software
access
licensed-software
fields.text: Do researchers have access to support for utilizing licensed software on shared resources?
fields.help_text: For example, do researchers have access to a common / shared software license server?

question: software
access
export-controlled
fields.text: Do researchers have access to support for managing export controlled software?

question: software
access
license-compliance
fields.text: Are processes defined and adhered to for educating, monitoring, and auditing Research Computing and Data staff, other IT professionals, and researchers, to comply with software license agreements?

question: software
physical_specimens
management
fields.text: Do researchers have access to management software for physical collections?

question: software
physical_specimens
discovery
fields.text: Do researchers have access to software for discovery and research use of physical collections?

question: software
physical_specimens
resources
fields.text: Do researchers have access to resources (e.g., staff) for software development for discovery and research use of physical collections?

question: systems
infrastructure
datacenter
fields.text: Do your systems-facing staff have access to a fully functional and reliable data center?
fields.help_text: For example, a full time IT operations and equipment facility?

question: systems
infrastructure
professional-management
fields.text: Is the data center professionally managed?
fields.help_text: For example are there dedicated FTEs, change management, 24/7, person-trap, closed circuit video, appropriate access controls and auditing?

question: systems
infrastructure
cloud-services
fields.text: Are there institutional resources for leveraging commercial cloud services for research computing and researchers?

question: systems
infrastructure
automation
fields.text: Are deployment, operations, and maintenance of your infrastructure automated?
fields.help_text: For example, using foreman, razor, puppet, ansible, chef, etc.

question: systems
infrastructure
containers
fields.text: Do systems staff have the skills and capacity to support container deployment and orchestration?
fields.help_text: For example, APIs, kubernetes, docker, singularity, etc.

question: systems
compute
high-performance
fields.text: Do researchers have access to high performance (batch) computing (HPC)?

question: systems
compute
high-throughput
fields.text: Do researchers have access to high throughput computing (HTC)?

question: systems
compute
production-level
fields.text: Do researchers have access to a production-level compute, storage, and network environment?

question: systems
compute
specialized-hardware
fields.text: Do researchers have access to specialized hardware capabilities, such as accelerators?
fields.help_text: For example, GPUs, TPUs, FPGAs, etc.

question: systems
compute
interactive
fields.text: Do researchers have access to interactive computing services?
fields.help_text: For example, support for VDI, Gateways, JupyterHub, etc.

question: systems
compute
standardized-os
fields.text: Is a standardized set of operating systems supported for HPC, workstations, and/or virtual machines?

question: systems
storage
scratch
fields.text: Do researchers have access to active data storage services (a.k.a., "scratch" storage, often a parallel filesystem) sufficient for HTC/HPC?

question: systems
storage
data-intensive
fields.text: Do researchers have access to sufficient storage to support researchers' data intensive computing needs?

question: systems
storage
security
fields.text: Do researchers have access to mechanisms for isolated and secure support for storage of sensitive/secure data?

question: systems
storage
management
fields.text: Do researchers have access to policies and technologies that facilitate management and wide access to data?
fields.help_text:
For example:
  • Automated tiering and data migration.
  • Security/compliance management support for sensitive/controlled data that require special access/export controls.

question: systems
storage
preservation
fields.text: Do researchers have access to data archival and preservation services (e.g. tape, cloud)?

question: systems
storage
final-research-data
fields.text: Do researchers have access to a place to store final research data to address institutional policy and/or funding agency requirements?

question: systems
storage
collaborations
fields.text: Do researchers have access to support for collaborative data grids and/or data repositories?
fields.help_text: These may be national, local, or commercial. For example, OSN, iRODS, etc.

question: systems
network
high-performance
fields.text: Do researchers have access to a high-performance network that supports research within campus?

question: systems
network
science-dmz
fields.text: Do researchers have access to a protected subnet or Science DMZ?
fields.help_text: A Science DMZ is a means to securely enable high performance inter-campus data flows that bypass campus firewalls.

question: systems
network
data-transfer
fields.text: Do researchers have access to support for high performance data movement with dedicated data transfer nodes (DTN) and associated data movement software?
fields.help_text: Software may include Globus, FDT, BBCP, or rclone, among others.

question: systems
network
buffering
fields.text: Do researchers have access to infrastructure for data buffering between high I/O lab instruments and the data center, and/or external resources?
fields.help_text: Examples may include “data capacitors” or “burst buffers”.

question: systems
network
security
fields.text: Do researchers have access to mechanisms for isolated and secure support for movement of sensitive/secure data?

question: systems
network
virtualization
fields.text: Do researchers have access to virtualized networking techniques such as Software Defined Networks, overlays, etc.?

question: systems
specialized
edge-computing
fields.text: Do researchers have access to support for edge computing and data resources?

question: systems
specialized
iot
fields.text: Do researchers have access to support for sensors, internet of things?

question: systems
specialized
workstations
fields.text: Do researchers have access to support for researcher workstations or laptops?

question: systems
specialized
special-instruments
fields.text: Do researchers have access to support for special science instruments?
fields.help_text: Examples may include Cryogenic electron microscopes (cryo-EM), DNA sequencers, telescopes, etc.

question: systems
specialized
testbeds
fields.text: Do researchers have access to specialized compute capability?
fields.help_text: Examples may include bare metal hardware, reconfigurable BIOS, OS, and network, or experimental cloud testbeds.

question: systems
software
resource-management
fields.text: Do researchers have access to resource management and/or queuing software for managing access to resources (e.g. SLURM, Torque)?

question: systems
software
identity-access-management
fields.text: Can researchers leverage institutional-level Identity and Access Management?

question: systems
software
2-factor-authentication
fields.text: Do researchers have access to 2-factor authentication (where prudent)?

question: systems
software
rbac
fields.text: Is researcher access to systems and data managed with a common, project-based or role-based tool?

question: systems
software
id-federation
fields.text: Are researchers' external collaborators able to use their home organization credentials (or ORCID IDs, etc.) to access systems and data?

question: systems
software
modules
fields.text: Do researchers have access to modules support to provide access to system-wide software libraries and applications?

question: systems
monitoring
node-level
fields.text: Is there a practice in place for monitoring infrastructure at the node (individual unit) level for resources that support research?

question: systems
monitoring
network-measurement
fields.text: Is there a practice in place utilizing active network measurement tools (i.e. perfSONAR) for the research-supporting network, DMZ, DTN etc.?

question: systems
monitoring
whole-system
fields.text: Is there a practice in place for whole system testing (e.g./chaos monkey) on resources that support research?

question: systems
monitoring
infrastructure-measurement
fields.text: Is there a practice in place for both active and passive measurement of infrastructure that supports research?

question: systems
monitoring
user-tools
fields.text: Do researchers have access to monitoring tools as part of their workflow?

question: systems
monitoring
performance-data
fields.text: Is performance data (on resources that support research) analyzed and used for operational decision making?

question: systems
monitoring
resource-usage
fields.text: Is a method in place to track and report resource usage at the researcher/project level?
fields.help_text: For example, for institutional and funding agency reporting purposes.

question: systems
recordkeeping
change-management
fields.text: Do Research Computing and Data staff follow a documented change management process?

question: systems
recordkeeping
version-control
fields.text: Do Research Computing and Data staff utilize version control repositories of services and infrastructure data?
fields.help_text: Also referred to as configuration management.

question: systems
recordkeeping
ticketing-system
fields.text: Do Research Computing and Data staff leverage a ticketing system for user support?

question: systems
recordkeeping
privileged-account-management
fields.text: Do Research Computing and Data staff follow an established procedure for privileged account management among the administrators, including tracking of elevated privileges?

question: systems
recordkeeping
network-performance
fields.text: Have Research Computing and Data staff established a workflow environment to support end-to-end network performance troubleshooting?

question: systems
documentation
maintenance
fields.text: Do Research Computing and Data staff produce and regularly maintain systems facing documentation?

question: systems
documentation
processes
fields.text: Do Research Computing and Data staff have documented processes, procedures, and policies for infrastructure management?

question: systems
planning
security-compliance
fields.text: Do Research Computing and Data planning processes include/incorporate security and compliance considerations?

question: systems
planning
procurement
fields.text: Do Research Computing and Data staff follow a formal process for procuring research computing, data, networking, etc. resources?
fields.help_text: For example, noting requirements, benchmarks, cost analysis, acceptance plans, terms and conditions, etc.

question: systems
planning
lifecycle
fields.text: Is a systems and infrastructure lifecycle plan defined and maintained?

question: systems
planning
user-engagement
fields.text: Are researchers and governance roles engaged to explore gaps and to address emerging needs and technologies?

question: systems
planning
emerging-technologies
fields.text: Are systems-facing staff engaged with exploring, testing, and deploying emerging or advanced technologies to help research?

question: systems
security
governance
fields.text: Is Research Computing and Data (RCD) security coordinated with institutional IT Security and Compliance?
fields.help_text:
For example:
  • Is the institutional IT security team leveraged for training and education?
  • Do RCD staff leverage institutional compliance resources/offices?

question: systems
security
best-practices
fields.text: Are Security Best practices implemented (such as those from NIST, trusted CI, CVE, and others)?
fields.help_text:
Example practices include:
  • Are security zones defined for different data sets and science workflows?
  • Is monitoring in use for intrusion detection, malware, and other threats?

question: systems
security
incident-response
fields.text: Is there a security incident response plan, and an associated response team?
fields.help_text:
Example practices include:
  • Are the associated procedures followed when incidents arise?
  • Are the plan and team membership reviewed on a regular basis (e.g., annually)?

question: strategy
alignment
strategic-plan
fields.text: Does your Research Computing and Data (RCD) team/group have a strategic plan, and is this strategic plan updated on a regular basis?
fields.help_text: For example, is there an annual or bi-annual review of your plan?

question: strategy
alignment
campus-plans
fields.text: Is your Research Computing and Data (RCD) strategic plan aligned to campus plans?
fields.help_text:
For example:
  • Does the RCD plan connect/relate to an institutional (campus-wide) strategic IT plan?
  • Does the RCD plan connect/relate to an overall institutional (campus-wide) strategic plan?

question: strategy
alignment
research-initiatives
fields.text: Do the Research Computing and Data (RCD) service and support community and underlying IT service providers have a good awareness and understanding of major research efforts/initiatives across the institution?

question: strategy
alignment
research-priorities
fields.text: Are research priorities, and Research Computing and Data (RCD) strategic priorities well-understood by your institution's management and planning groups?
fields.help_text:
Example measures may include:
  • Are the institution's research priorities well-understood by campus leadership?
  • Are RCD strategic priorites understood and supported by campus leadership?

question: strategy
alignment
faculty-advisory-group
fields.text: Is there a Faculty Advisory Group (or equivalent) that provides review and advice on priorities for the Research Computing and Data (RCD) program?
fields.help_text:
• Does this group meet regularly (e.g., quarterly or once a semester) to review and advise?
  • This is generally a dedicated group for RCD, although it may be part of a larger research or IT advisory body.

question: strategy
alignment
recognition
fields.text: Does institution-level management and planning recognize and value the impact of Research Computing and Data (including return/value on investment)?
fields.help_text: For example, are research computing and data services valued at the same level as or higher than other enterprise services when discussing of prioritization of campus (budget) resources?

question: strategy
alignment
awareness
fields.text: Are researchers effectively informed and made aware of Research Computing and Data (RCD) resources and services?
fields.help_text:
For example:
  • Is there an institutionally defined role that includes responsibility to create awareness of RCD resources and services available on campus or externally?
  • Are RCD services documented in an accessible platform, such as an IT service catalog?
  • Is the importance of outreach and training recognized by campus leadership?

question: strategy
alignment
pedagogy
fields.text: Are Research Computing and Data (RCD) resources and services available in support of instruction or other pedagogical uses?
fields.help_text:
For example:
  • Can and do instructors leverage research computing resources for instruction?
  • Are instructors effectively informed about available resources?

question: strategy
culture
rcd-understanding
fields.text: Is there an understanding across the IT organization, research community, and institutional leadership of the distinction between Research Computing and Data services and standard (enterprise) IT services?
fields.help_text: Note: This does not imply greater importance of one or the other, nor is it meant to imply how an organization should support each. Rather, it is a recognition that the goals, constraints, metrics, and support models tend to be quite different.

question: strategy
culture
rcd-importance
fields.text: Is facilitation of Research Computing and Data services recognized as an important role to the campus?

question: strategy
culture
metrics
fields.text: Are Research Computing and Data operating metrics captured and reported to leadership?
fields.help_text: For example, is this data shared with IT leadership, Office of Research, or other institutional leadership)?

question: strategy
funding
sustainable
fields.text: Are Research Computing and Data services funded in a sustainable manner?
fields.help_text:
For example:
  • Is there recurring program budget for the staff and services operations (i.e., not primarily dependent upon grants or other non-recurring funding)?
  • Are campus funding partnerships formalized with an MOU or equivalent agreement?
  • For activities funded from contracts and grants, is there a strong track-record of renewed funding?

question: strategy
funding
opportunities
fields.text: Are new funding opportunities proactively identified and assessed at an institutional level, for relevance to institutional mission and alignment to Research Computing and Data needs and priorities?

question: strategy
funding
research-funding
fields.text: Do research funding activities actively integrate the Research Computing and Data (RCD) services group?
fields.help_text:
For example:
  • Do RCD groups/teams collaborate with the Contracts and Grants groups/teams?
  • Do RCD staff assist Principle Investigators (PIs) with proposal preparation?

question: strategy
funding
extramural-grants
fields.text: Do Research Computing and Data (RCD) services groups/teams submit (extramural) grant proposals for RCD investments and innovations?

question: strategy
funding
awarded-grants
fields.text: Have Research Computing and Data (RCD) services groups/teams been awarded (extramural) grants they applied for, in support of RCD investments and innovation?

question: strategy
partnerships
regional-national
fields.text: Do Research Computing and Data (RCD) services groups/teams actively engage with regional and/or national Research Computing and Data peers/communities?
fields.help_text: For example, regional research network providers, CaRCC, CASC, Internet2, Campus Champions, NSF regional Big Data Hub, etc.

question: strategy
partnerships
external-users
fields.text: Are institutional Research Computing and Data services provided to external users, such as hosting data repositories, providing computing resources, etc.?
fields.help_text: For example, are you a provider to XSEDE or the Open Science Grid (OSG)?

question: strategy
partnerships
external-partnerships
fields.text: Is there a practice of active engagement of your institution in external partnerships (for funding, or for advancing Research Computing and Data activities and interests?
fields.help_text: For example, are there regional partnerships, and/or active industry partnerships?

question: strategy
professionalization
training
fields.text: Are Research Computing and Data (RCD) staff provided with professional training opportunities?
fields.help_text:
For example:
  • Do RCD staff have access to funding for training?
  • Does each RCD staff member have a professional development plan?

question: strategy
professionalization
career-advancement
fields.text: Are Research Computing and Data staff provided with opportunities for career advancement?
fields.help_text:
For example:
  • Are there clear career paths defined for each role?
  • Are staff encouraged/supported in pursuing career advancement opportunities?

question: strategy
professionalization
community-engagement
fields.text: Are Research Computing and Data (RCD) staff permitted to use staff time to engage in regional or national community efforts?
fields.help_text:
For example:
  • Do RCD staff participate in regional networks, Campus Champions work, Linux user groups, CaRCC, etc.?
  • Do RCD staff contribute to the Carpentries work (training materials or activities)?

question: strategy
diversity
policy-practice
fields.text: Is there a policy and practice to ensure (and if necessary, improve) diversity, equity, and inclusion, on the Research Computing and Data (RCD) staff?
fields.help_text:
For example:
  • Are RCD staff regularly surveyed on engagement, cultural climate, etc.?
  • Does RCD management track this over time?
  • Are the results used to develop ongoing strategies to improve diversity, equity, and inclusion?

question: strategy
diversity
inclusive-language
fields.text: Are Research Computing and Data recruitments (job listings) reviewed for inclusive language to attract a broad range of applicants?

question: strategy
diversity
training
fields.text: Do Research Computing and Data staff have access to diversity, equity, and inclusion training?
fields.help_text: For example, on unconscious bias, communication styles, multicultural awareness, etc.

question: researcher
domain-support
arts-and-humanities
fields.text: Do you support research in the Arts and Humanities?
fields.help_text: This can include: Languages and Language Arts, History, Philosophy, Performing Arts, Visual Arts, etc.

question: researcher
domain-support
earth-geo-sciences
fields.text: Do you support research in the Earth and Geosciences?
fields.help_text: This can include: Atmospheric Science, Ecology, Environmental Sciences, Geography, Geology, Hydrology, Oceanography, Soil Sciences, etc.

question: researcher
domain-support
cs-and-infosci
fields.text: Do you support research in Computer and Information Sciences?
fields.help_text: This can include Computer Science, Information Science, etc.

question: researcher
domain-support
med-school
fields.text: Do you support research in a Medical School?
fields.help_text: If your institution has a separate medical school, how well are researchers there supported? (If your institution does not have a medical school, you can mark this as “Question not Applicable.”)

question: researcher
domain-support
engineering
fields.text: Do you support research in Engineering?
fields.help_text: This can include: Chemical Engineering, Civil Engineering, Electrical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, etc.

question: researcher
domain-support
social-sciences
fields.text: Do you support research in the Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences?
fields.help_text: This can include: Anthropology, Archaeology, Communication Science, Economics, Human Geography, Linguistics, Management Science, Political science, etc.

question: researcher
domain-support
bio-life-sciences
fields.text: Do you support research in the Biological and Life Sciences?
fields.help_text: This can include: Anatomy, Bacteriology, Bioinformatics, Biology, Botany, Entomology, Genetics, Immunology, Microbiology, Molecular and Cell Biology, Neuroscience, Physiology,  Virology, Zoology, etc.

question: researcher
domain-support
chem-phys-sciences
fields.text: Do you support research in Chemistry, Physics, and Astronomy/Space Sciences?
fields.help_text: This can include: Biochemistry, Inorganic Chemistry, Organic Chemistry, Physical Chemistry, Materials Science, Physics, Astronomy, Astrophysics,Cosmology, Planetary Sciences, Space Sciences, etc.
